channel.title: nucl-ex updates on arXiv.org
channel.description: nucl-ex updates on the arXiv.org e-print archive.

item.title: Photoproduction of heavy vector mesons in peripheral $PbPb$ collisions at the Large Hadron Collider
item.description: arXiv:2505.14019v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: A comprehensive analysis of the photoproduction of $J/\Psi$ and $\Upsilon$ mesons in peripheral $PbPb$ collisions at the center - of - mass energies of the Large Hadron Collider (LHC) is performed, considering distinct assumptions for the modeling of the nuclear photon flux, photon - nucleus cross - section, overlap function and dipole - proton scattering amplitude. The comparison of these predictions with the ALICE data is also performed. Our results indicate that a detailed analysis of the production of both mesons will be very useful to improve the description of photon - induced processes in peripheral collisions.
item.dc:creator: Pedro E. A. da Costa, Andr\'e V. Giannini, Victor P. Goncalves, Bruno D. Moreira

item.title: First Results on the Search for Lepton Number Violating Neutrinoless Double Beta Decay with the LEGEND-200 Experiment
item.description:
arXiv:2505.10440v2 Announce Type: cross Abstract: The LEGEND collaboration is searching for neutrinoless double beta ($0
u eta eta$) decay by operating high-purity germanium detectors enriched in $^{76}$Ge in a low-background liquid argon environment. Building on key technological innovations from GERDA and the MAJORANA DEMONSTRATOR, LEGEND-200 has performed a first $0
u eta eta$ decay search based on 61 kg yr of data. Over half of this exposure comes from our highest performing detectors, including newly developed inverted-coaxial detectors, and is characterized by an estimated background level of $0.5^{+0.3}_{-0.2}$ cts/(keV kg yr) in the $0
u eta eta$ decay signal region. A combined analysis of data from GERDA, the MAJORANA DEMONSTRATOR, and LEGEND-200, characterized by a 90% confidence level exclusion sensitivity of $2.8 	imes 10^{26}$ yr on the half-life of $0
u eta eta$ decay, reveals no evidence for a signal and sets a new observed lower limit at $T^{0
u}_{1/2} > 1.9 	imes 10^{26}$ yr (90% confidence level). Assuming the decay is mediated by Majorana neutrinos, this corresponds to an upper limit on the effective Majorana mass in the range $m_{ eta eta} < 75-200$ meV, depending on the adopted nuclear matrix element.

item.title: Review of Neutron Yield from (${\alpha}$, n) Reactions: Data, Methods, and Prospects
item.description: arXiv:2405.07952v4 Announce Type: replace Abstract: Understanding the radiogenic neutron production rate through the (${\alpha}$, n) reaction is crucial in many areas of physics, including dark matter searches, neutrino studies, and nuclear astrophysics. In addition to its relevance for fundamental research, the (${\alpha}$, n) reaction also plays a significant role in nuclear energy technologies, for example by contributing to neutron production in subcritical systems using UO$_{2}$, as well as in applications such as medical physics. This review examines the current state of (${\alpha}$, n) yield calculations and neutron spectra, describes the computational tools used for their estimation, and discusses the available cross-section data. We explore the uncertainties affecting (${\alpha}$, n) yield estimations and propose a strategy to enhance their accuracy. Furthermore, this paper discusses and emphasizes the need for new measurements of (${\alpha}$, n) cross-sections for a variety of relevant materials. Such measurements are essential for improving neutron flux predictions, which are crucial for reducing uncertainties in sensitivity estimates for next-generation physics experiments operating in the keV--MeV range.
item.dc:creator: D. Cano-Ott, S. Cebri\'an, P. Dimitriou, M. Gromov, M. Hara\'nczyk, A. Kish, H. Kluck, V. A. Kudryavtsev, I. Lazanu, V. Lozza, G. Luz\'on, E. Mendoza, M. Parvu, V. Pesudo, A. Pocar, R. Santorelli, M. Selvi, S. Westerdale, G. Zuzel

item.title: Probing Pion Valence Quark Distribution with Beam-charge Asymmetry of Pion-induced $J/\psi$ Production
item.description: arXiv:2503.18654v2 Announce Type: replace-cross Abstract: We consider the beam-charge asymmetry of the $J/\psi$ production cross sections in $\pi^-$- versus $\pi^+$-induced reactions on proton or nuclear targets. We show that the $J/\psi$ production cross section difference between $\pi^-$ and $\pi^+$ beams impinging on a proton target has a positive sign with a magnitude proportional to the product of pion's valence quark distribution, $V_\pi$, and proton's up and down valence quark distribution difference, $u^V - d^V$. The existing $J/\psi$ production data for $\pi^- + p$ and $\pi^+ + p$ at 39.5 and 200 GeV/c are consistent with the expected positive beam-charge asymmetry. The magnitude of the asymmetry is compared with calculations performed within two theoretical frameworks, the Color Evaporation Model (CEM) and the Non-Relativistic QCD (NRQCD) formalism. We also examine the beam-charge dependence for pion-induced $J/\psi$ production cross sections measured on the neutron-rich platinum target, and find good agreement between the data and theory for both the negative sign and the magnitude of the beam-charge asymmetry. The comparison between data and theoretical calculations for both proton and platinum targets suggests that the beam-charge asymmetry in pion-induced $J/\psi$ production is a viable method of accessing the valence quark distribution of the pion.
item.dc:creator: Wen-Chen Chang, Marco Meyer-Conde, Jen-Chieh Peng, Stephane Platchkov, Takahiro Sawada
